div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.

TO-DAY'S TELEGRAMS.

div.head: PORT ARTHUR
div.p: JAPANESE SUCCESS.
DESTRUCTION IN HARBOUR.
RUSSIAN SHIPS SUNK.
· JAPS WAITING OUTSIDE.
TOKIO, December 7. Another 5 hours armistice was agreed upon yesterday at Port Arthur, as the Russians desired to remove their dead.
The battleship Poltava has been sunk. The battleship Retoisan is listing badly, and the cruiser Bayan is stranded. The Japanese have occupied Akasaba Hill.
(Reuter.)
CHi-Fu, December 7. Subsequent to the occupation of Akasaba bill, the Japanese captured two other hills near It-shan.
(Reuter.)
Tokio, December 7. The Japanese bombardment at Port Arthur hassunk the "Poltava and damaged the Retvisan.
(Havas.)

Chr-Fu, December 8. The Japanese bombardment of the harbor was continued yesterday. Many shots took effect. The Peresviet was ignited. The Retvisan has been apparently sunk, and the Pobieda is listing to starboard.
(Reuter.)
Tokyo, December 8. The Japanese continue to bombard Port Arthur, aiming at the battleships Pallada, Peresviet, and Pobieda.
(Havas.)

Chi-Fu, December 8. The Peresviet has sunk and is submerged. The Ketvisan is nearly submerged. The PoHieda's stern is submerged. The Pallada is slightly sinking astern. The Sevastopol also appears to be sinking. The Bayan is on fire.
A steamer reports that she saw a strong Japanese squadron outside Port Arthur. It is believed that the entire fleet is there now.
(Reuter.) 1
SCENE ON 203-METRE HILL.

LONDON, December 8. Reuter's correspondent before Port Arthur, who visited the 203-metre hill at the close of a week's struggle, says the scene was awful. The crest of the bill was torn away and the trenches semi-obliterated. In a single section of 100 yards of trenches there were 200 Russian dead and wounded, horribly mangled by dynamite and grenades.
(Reuter.)

div.head: MANCHURIA.
div.p: ACTIVITY OF CHUN-CHUSES
TREMENDOUS CANNONADING.

St. PETERSBURG, December 7. The Russian correspondents at Mukden constantly refer to the activity of the Chunchuses, who are now well organized under the famous leader Tulisan. They are specially troublesome in their attempts to blow up bridges and the railway.
(Reuter.)

MUKDEN, December 7. A tremendous cannonading with siege guns began yesterday morning round Putiloff bill and the railway. The number of guns is constantly increasing. It is supposed that important developments will follow. (Reuter.)

div.head: DUKE OF CONNAUGHT.
div.p: RECEIVED BY THE POPE.
ROME, December 7. - The Duke of Connaught has been received ju audience by the Pope.
(Reuter.)

div.head: TRAGIC DEATH OF M. SYVETON.
div.p: ASPHYXIATED IN HIS ROOM.
Paris, December 8, 31. Syveton has died, having been asphyxiate ed through an escape of gas in his study,
(Havas.)
PARIS, December 9. M. Syveton, the aggressor of General André, "has been found dead, asphyxiated by gas in his study,
(Reuters)

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET.
div.p: COALING OF VESSELS.
DEPARTURE FROM TANGIER.

PERIM, December 7. The yacht Catarina, from Djibouti, contradicts the dhows' report to the effect that the Russians had coaled at Musha. All the ships coaled at Djibouti from their own colliers, and also reprovisioned there.
(Reuter.)
TANGIER, December 7. The rest of Admiral Botrovosky's squadron, consisting of the cruiser Dnieper (ex Petersburg), two destroyers, and a transport, have left, travelling eastwards.
(Reuter.)
BREST, December 8. The destroyer Pronzitelni, mentioned on the 29th November, was repaired, and has since left.
(Reuter.)

div.head: COAL FOR THE BALTIC FLEET.
div.p: LONDON, December 8. The German collier Bengalia sailed from Cardiff for Batavia with 12,000 tons of coal, which it is believed is for the Baltic Fleet.
(Reuter.)

div.head: THIRD RUSSIAN SQUADRON.
div.p: LONDON, December 8. The Daily Mail learns from St. Petersburg that the Tsar yesterday decreed the despatch of a third squadron, which will not be composed of Black Sea vessels.
(Reuter.)

div.head: GENERAL NEWS.
div.p: ANGLO-FRENCH CONVENTION.
ADOPTED BY SENATE.
Paris, December 7. The Senate has adopted the Anglo-French Convention by 215 votes to 37. (Reuter.)

PARIS, December 7. The Senate has passed the Anglo-French Convention. M. Delcassé spoke of the happy | results of the entente with England and the advantages obtained in West Africa and Morocco, which compensate for the concessions made in Egypt and Newfoundland. (Havas.)

Paris, December 8. The Senate adopted without a division the Franco-Siamese Convention. M. Delcassé said that this treaty would assure to France a I preponderance in the Mekong Basin without moving a single soldier, or expending a centime.

Replying to the debate on the Anglo-French Convention, M. Delcassé said that his opponents had concentrated their criticisms on the question of Newfoundland, yet all that France had abandoned was the valueless fish-erring rights, and she had received in exchange important compensation elsewhere. This Convention was the result of a foreign policy based upon a plan which had been followed perseveringly for six years. In consequence of such plan, Spain and Italy had been conciliated and Great Britain no longer saw in France anything else but a tried worker, whom it would be difficult to replace in the field of peace and concord.
(Reuter.)

div.head: AUSTRIA AND TURKEY.
div.p: ULTIMATUM TO THE PORTE.
VIENNA, December 8. Austria has presented' an ultimatum to Turkey demanding the punishment of the Scutari officials who detained the mails. Unless this is done, the fleet will proceed to the Levant.
(Reuter.)
VIENNA, December 8. Turkey has agreed to secede to Austria's | demands. The incident is now regarded as closed.
(Reuter.)
ENGLAND'S TRADE.
BIG INCREASE IN EXPORTS.

LONDON, December 7. The exports during November show an increase of £3,000,000 and the imports of £2,000,000 compared with last year. During the 11 months tile increases are £6,500,000 for exports and £8,000,000 for imports. (R.)

div.head: AMERICAN COTTON.
div.p: MOVEMENT AMONG PLANTERS.
NEW ORLEANS, December 8. The plaiters in the cotton-growing States. have summoned mass meetings here, in order to devise some means of holding back the cotton.
(Reuter.)

div.head: PRINCE FAZIL AT MARSEILLES.
div.p: MARSEILLES, December 8. Prince Fazil has arrived. (Havas.)

div.head: THE CHRISTMAS TREE
div.p: entertainment at Shepheard's Hotel will take place on the 25th inst. Invitations will be issued next week.

div.head: A POSTAL ERROR.-
div.p: We regret to state that the issue of the Gazette of Saturday last for our Ramleh subscribers was despatched to Cairo through an error of the Post Office.

div.head: RABIES.
div.p: There are an unusually large number of dog-bitten people at Kasr-el-Aini Hospital, Cairo, now. We hear 60 mentioned, though, of course, there is no proof that all the dogs were mad.

div.head: To BOOK LOVERS.--
div.p: Mr. Marschner, the wellknown Cairo bookseller, has published an interesting list of new and second-hand books, chiefly Oriental and mostly from the library of the late Dr. C. Reinhardt, Consul at Bushir. Booklovers who have not received this list may have it post-free on application to Diemer's Bookstall, P. O. B. 311, Cairo.

div.head: HELOUAN.-
div.p: In reference to a notice issued recently by the management of the Tewfik Palace Hotel, Helouan, residents and visitors may be reminded that the trains from Bab-elLouk station leave for Helouan at 9.10, 10.10, and 12.10, and not at 9.15, 10.15, and 12.10. Luncheon is served at. 1 p.m.

div.head: Suez Canal.-
div.p: On the 5th inst. 10 vessels passed through the canal, 5 of which were British, 2 Austrian, 1 French, 1 Italian, 1 Dutch. On this day the receipts were frs. 276,329.34. On the 6th the number of vessels was 17, of which 13 were British, 1 Austrian, 1 German, 1 French, 1 Dutch, the receipts for the day being frs. 448,953.56. From the 1st to the 6th inst, the total receipts amounted to Irs. 2,256,088.50.

div.head: A VENDETTA AT Kafr ZAYAT.--
div.p: The longstanding dispute between two well-known native families of Katr Zayat, the Pazari and the Rukubani, culminated some weeks ago in a street fight in which some of the former family were badly beaten. The Mulahiz of the police at Kafr Layat is accused by the Fazaris of having been very negligent in coming to their help and they have denounced that othcial to the Parquet. The matter is still under consideration by the Parquet, whose decision is awaited with great interest by the people of Katr Zayat.

div.head: "THE SPHINX." -
div.p: This Cairo winter weekly journal has made its eleventh annual appear ance in an entirely new dress, which suits it | admirably. This first number contains some very interesting contributions which appeal to the resiuent and visitor alike, and a feature is made of financial news of a very informing character, to which a whole page is devoted. We believe that, as the season | advances, new features, more intimately connected with the movements and doings of our winter guests, will be added, and the attractiveness of the publication enhanced by half-tone illustrations of local and topical events. It is the aim of the editor to make his I journal reflect the non-political views of the
residents of the Capital, and he hopes to receive the co-operation of the latter in his task. The quality of the paper and printing leaves nothing to be desired.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive proceeded yesterday morning to Koubbeh Mosque, where he attended Bey. ram prayers.
The Beyram reception held at Abdeen Palace by his Highness was very largely attended.
To-morrow his Highness will open the horticultural exhibition at Ghezireh at 3 p.m.

CHRISTMAS DAY. We hear that the British professors employed in the Secondary Schools at Cairo will not, this year, get their Christmas Day free. Up to this year they have been, almost without exception, allowed a holiday on December 25, but this year, it is said, owing to the fact that the Arabic professors are unable to take the whole day's work through insufficiency in numbers, they will lose it.

We are, of course, aware that Christmas Day, like other European holidays, cannot, in a Moslem country, be observed to the same extent as in England, but we think it a pity that the authorities of the Ministry of Public Instruction cannot see their way to grant the concession to men,-many of whom are married and would naturally prefer to spend the day at home, who have done bard, and in some cases rather monotonous, work for some time past.

THE LATE MRS. WILSON. The funeral of the late Mrs. W. J. Wilson took place yesterday morning at the Old British Protestant Cemetery at Alexandria, and was attended by many of the older members of the British Colony. The body was brought from Cairo by the only son of the deceased lady, Mr. Louis Wilson, and the funeral service was conducted by the Rey. W. Wormell.

PRINCE'S VISIT TO EGYPT.
PRINCE LEOPOLD ARRIVING
ON TUESDAY.

Prince Leopold of Battenberg left Kensington Palace this day week for Egypt. His Highness travelled from Liverpool-street by the P. and O. boat train express to Tilbury, where he embarked on the steamship Arabia for Port Said. Princess Henry of Battenberg and Princess Ena were present at the station to bid him good-bye. Lord William Cecil travelled with the Prince to Tilbury. His Highness is expected at Port Said on Tuesday next and will proceed straight to Cairo. Lord Cecil has engaged a suite of rooms for his Highness at the Hotel d'Angleterre.

THE SINAI EXPEDITION. Mr. Monk Porch, the well-known Oxonian Egyptologist, who is on his way to explore the Sinai-tic peninsula in company with Pro essor Flinders Petrie, has arrived at Suez and will start from there by camel. It is well known that in ancient times large amounts of malachite were brought to Alexandria from Sinai, and it is hoped that a large business may be developed by reviving the export of this beautiful mineral.

Professor Flinders Petrie, whose age will not enable him to endure as much campaigning in the desert as he would like, will not undertake the search for flint instruments, which is a subject very dear to Mr. Monk Porch's heart. This search for malachite is a somewhat new departure for the professor, who has hitherto confined his attention more to antiquities than to commerce. The conjunction of these two able men should result in some very interesting researches, as Sinai is in a great measure an undiscovered country.
The old malachite mines are believed to have been located, but they have not been explored in recent times.
NUNGOVICH HOTELS. The election of the directors of the Nungovich Hotels Company has been postponed owing to the illness of Dr. Page-May, who is suffering from influenza.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: LA GIOCONDA. Ponchielli's tuneful and favorite opera La Gioconda is so well-known, and so truly appreciated by the majority of the opera-going I public, that no surprise need be expressed at the audience which assembled last evening and taxed the seating accommodation of the house to its utmost limits. In spite of this, however, the performance failed to draw the house to any very great extent in the first or second acts, and there appeared to be an unaccountable coldness on each side of the footlights; even the moon beat & very hasty retreat. It was not until the closing of the third act, with its tragic scene and magnificent finale, that the audience were thoroughly roused, and all the artistes concerned were enthusiastically recalled again and again. As La Gioconda Sigpa. Amelia Pinto created a very favorable impression, both acting and singing with much artistic skill. Such a performance augurs well for the success of the several operas in which this lady is to appear. Signa. Margherita Julia was not altogether what we had anticipated as Laura Adorno. If the business so painfully evident occasionally, in the lower register, was due to cold, Signa. Julis was certainly very brave to have come forward. Her performance otherwise was exceedingly good. In the role of Enzo Grimaldi Sig. Francesco Bravi did not appear to be quite at ease, but whatever he lacked histrionically he certainly made up for vocally. Signor Bravi possesses a fine voice, which he has under good control, and although rather light for an opera such as Gioconda, he scored a distinct success. His rendering of the favorite "Cielo e mar" naturally brought forth the usual rounds of applause and consequent encore. As Alvise Badoero, Sig. Carlo Walter acted with dignity and sang, as he always does, with effect. Sig. Enrico Nani's performance was one much above the average, his singing and acting being of high artistic merit throughout the opera. Sig. Nani I will undoubtedly become a great favorite during the season. The very distressing character of La Cieca was ably sustained by Signa. Adele Ponzano. The two ballets danced during the evening were well executed, and the chorus was even better than usual, the invisible chorus in particular being exceedingly well rendered. Under the able bâton of Sig. Setti the orchestra was excellent, although in the third act and finale the eyeballs worked rather more than was pleasant for those sitting near.
ALHAMBRA THEATRE.

There was a large house at the Alhambra | last night to welcome the new variety and ballet company which is now occupying the boards. The company is composed of very good elements, and an excellent show was presented. It would take up more space than we have at our disposal to enumerate the various "turns" on the programme, so many and varied are these, but the performances of "The Stewarts," equilibrists, Bepoil, French comique (who is, by the way, an old favorite here), Mlle Rosensteel, "diseuse," Mlle Mignon, balladist, and Mlle Ivon Hett, la poupée Parisienne, are worthy of special mention. We must candidly confess the ballet, Les Amours du Papillon, did not come up to our expectations, but this was probably due to the fact, announced, that no less than three of the fair participants were indisposed. We hope for better things in future.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expresseded by our correspondent, but which, in spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain nasality limits our discussion.

div.head: ICE SUPPLY OF ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,--Having read the article on the above subject in your issue of yesterday's date, and being interested in the ice business, will you please allow us a brief space for a reply. Just previous to the commencement of the ice season--unfortunately for the public as well as the owners-the Société Anonymous Moulins d'Egypte's ice-works and flour-mills were almost entirely destroyed by fire, and out of four tree plants one only remained intact. The motor power having been destroyed by the fire, it was impossible to put these three ice plants again in working condition in time for the season ; consequently the above-named company were
only working one plant instead of four, which in reduced their output of ice to twelve tons re instead of forty-eight. The reason as to how the
fourth ice plant could be worked, is that this is I plant is completely isolated from the others, and

11 connected to separate motor-power. Had this of company been working all four ice plants, the mountain of ice in Alexandria would certainly as have been more than sufficient to meet the of public requirements. It is easy to see from
the above the reason why ice was high in m price, but the extra profit did not go into the
-pockets of the ice manufacturers, it was u reaped by the retail vendors, who took - advantage of an exceptional situation. In r. conclusion we may add that the three ice
plants of the Sooiété Anonyme des Moulins e d'Egypte have been again erected, and are in a position to be worked next season.
Thanking you for your space,

TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE,
Sir,--Frequent complaints are heard of dilatoriness on the part of the Telephone Co., | but action amounting to breach of contract is, - I hope, rare. My experience of a few days ago
is the following: | A customer in Ramleh, who is & subscriber to

the Telephone Co., endeavored to telephone to me relative to the repetition of an important order and also for some urgently-wanted medicine for his wife. To his astonishment communication was refused him, the employé informing him that, were he to do so, it would entail loss of his post. Imagining that & mistake had occurred, my client again endeavored to communicate with me, but met with refusal on three separate occasions. He then, at considerable loss of time and inconvenience, came to Alexandria and gave the order in person.
I take it for granted that the aim and Te object of the Telephone Company is to furnish

telephonic communication amongst subscribers, and with a view to information on the subject, and this particular case in question, I wrote to the Alexandria manager per registered letter and telegraphed to the general manager in Cairo requesting an explanation. This I probably being to them & matter of sueh frequent occurrence and of so little moment, neither of the aforesaid gentlemen thought fit to reply to my letter or telegram. I therefore crave the courtesy of your paper with a view to learning if other subscribers have been treated in a like manner.
Yours truly,

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: CRICKET.
CAIRO.. ALEXANDRIA.

The Cairo Alexandria cricket match began yesterday in very uncertain and squally weather, which several times interrupted play. Alexandria began well, having 140 on the | board for 8 wickets before lunch, owing to some fine batting by H. B. Carver, the two
Maclarens, and Strange. After lunch, how however, the whole side got out for 199, Lockett i and Graves getting the wickets. Cairo began
badly in losing Lockett, who had hard luck in getting out off his pads, but thanks to Capt. Potter, who played a very steady innings and
was not out at the close of play, they did a better than their start promised. At the close el of play the score was 58 for 3 wickets, so that Alexandria may be said to hold a decided lead.

The Married v. Single cricket match on Saturday will not be played. A Rugby football match, Cairo e. The Provinces, will replace it, and will certainly be more seasonable, to judge from the weather that ushered in Beyram

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Among the passengers who arrived at Port Said on Wednesday by the S.S. India were the Earl of Londesborough, Lord George Cbolmondeley, Lord Newton, Lord Redstockz Sir James Blyth, Sir Everard Doyle, Sir Robert Repner, M.P., and Lady Ropner and Sir Edward and Lady Stone.
H. E. Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, the Prime Minister, H.E. Mahmud Sidky Pasha, Governor of Alexandria, and Izzet Bey Choucry are spending the Beyram holidays at Mena
House.
Among others spending the holidays under the shadow of the Pyramids are Mrs. Du Boylay, Mr. Carter Wilson, Capt. Herbert, Miss Strachan, Miss B. M. Board, Miss Morrison, Dr Herbert W. Brown.
Many prominent Alexandrian’s arrived in Cairo for the Levée, among them Rear-Admiral Sir M. Blomfield, K.C.M.G., Michalla Pasha, Chitty Bey, and Mr. Macaulay.
Rear-Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield returned from Cairo yesterday evening.
Chitty Bey, Director General of Customs, will return from Cairo to-morrow morning.
Ahmed Pasha Fareed arrived yesterday evening from Cairo.

We deeply regret to announce the death of Mrs. Kyriacopoulo, the mother of our excellent confrère, Mr. Achilles Kyriacopoulo, proprietor and editor of the well-known Greek paper of Alexandria, Telegraphs. The funeral will take place this afternoon at 3 o'clock.

EGYPTIAN SHARE MARKET. (FROM OUR FINANCIAL CORRESPONDENT.)

London, December. 4. The political situation since our last has not had much effect on Stock Exchange prices. A further delay has taken place in the negotiations foreshadowed in our previous article, owing to the fact that the war party in Russia had again got the upper hand, and have been trying to utilize the Indian frontier question to delay matters. One of the features in Egyptian stocks this week has been the renewed demand for Salt and Soda shares. The supply of shares on this market being almost exhausted, the natural result is that a further considerable advance in price has taken place, and there are at this moment large buying orders at 42s. which are still unsupplied. The price is an exaggerated one and offers a fine opportunity for profit-taking; at the same time those on your side who understand the position of affairs of this company will be able to draw their own conclusions. There has also been during the past week an active market in Egyptian Mining shares, notably Nile Valleys and United Africans. The former have been over 31. and the latter 2. There has been a set back from those prices during the last day or two, due in part to profit-taking, and it is also stated that the outside broker company which has had to meet its creditors had considerable interests in these shares.

It looks as if the check is only a temporary one; the market might take a fresh start at any moment. United Africans, which have fallen to 15 (their price to-day), look, cheap. It is said that they have, in cash and liquid assets, sufficient to pay about £2.10.0. per share. Bank shares are steady, Nationals 231, and Agricultural 104. Delta Light Railway Preference are & strong market at 15 and look like going better still, on their satisfactory report just issued. In general markets South Africans are easier-but with a good undertone, and a decided widening of business. Internationals are firm on the whole, and the American Market remains & wonderfully good one.

div.head: L'AVENIR DE L'EGYPTE
div.p: Sous ce titre un confrère de Marseille publie un intéressant aperçu de l'avenir de l'Egypte au point de vue commercial:-

"Les commerçants, dit-il, réclament des travaux publics. Its se plaignent du défaut d'aménagement dans le port d'Alexandrie, de la difficulté des communications entre le Caire et ce port, de l'insuffisance des moyens de relations entre la Haute et la Basse-Egypte. Ils tracent un programme de travaux qui comprend trois entreprises considérables: création d'un nouveau bassin dans le port d'Al-xandrie, création d'un port fluvial au Caire, travaux qui assurent la navigabilité du Ni. L'ensemble de ces travaux gravite autour d'un point central: le Caire. Il s'agit de faire de la capitale politique de l'Egypte the capitale économique. Au Caire abou- firaient comme un carrefour de canaux les produits venant de Suez et ceux venant de de Khartoum. De là, ceux qui servent à l'approvisionnement du Delta seraient di rigés sur les divers points, les principales villes. Le Caire deviendrait un centre de dispersion, de répartition entre les divers marchés intérieurs.

"Quant aux produits qui ne sont point destinés à la population résidant en Egypte, prodaits d'exportation venant de la Haute- Egypte, ils seraient dirigés par canaux vers Alexandrie. Le Caire serait l'amorce d'ute voie de transit. Au résultat, l'activité de 8 l'Egypte serait multipliée par le perfectionnement de l'industrie de ses transports C'est là le côté local, égyptien, de ce programme de travaux publics."

Après ce préambule, l'auteur de l'article, envisageant la question au point de vue & purement français, préconise un redouble-d ment d'activité entre la France et l'Egypte, la création de services plus rapides, l'ac croissement du mouvement commercial, etc.

div.head: La Mosquee du Sultan Hassan
div.p: A la séance du 2 mai dernier de l'Insti-I tut Egyptien, Abbate pacha ayant protestée contre les merlons fort laids et mal placés I de la mosquée et ayant prié ses collègues de s'unir à lui pour demander au Comité de t conservation des monuments de l'art arabe 8 de faire disparaître les ornemente "banaux D et non authentiques" qui sont un crime t de "èse-architecture" commis au préjudice f de la belle et imposante mosquée, le Comité de l'art arabe fut saisi de la question. De s graves personnages ficent l'ascension de la t mosquée pour s'enquérir si les merlous t avaient existé dans la corniche.

Dans la séance de lundi, Abbate Pacha o s'est efforcé de démontrer que les merlons b n'avaient jamais existé. Il s'est basé pour cela sur les Baedekers et sur l'absence de toute trace d'encadrement sur la corniche.

Herz bey n'assistait pas à la séance pour nous faire entendre le second son de cloche, mais S. E. Fakkry pacha a réponda en quelques mots qu'on s'est occupé des notes aux séances du Comité de l'art arabe et qu'on a délégué une Commission pour s'assurer de l'exactitude des faits.
M. Fourtau a clos le débat par la simple P lecture du paragraphe euivant de La Vie Littéraire, d'Anatole France:-

"Didron, qui aima les vieilles pierres, inscrivit peu de temps avant sa mort, sur l'album d'un ami, ce précepte sage et méprisé. En faits de monuments anciens, il vaut mieux consolider que réparer, mieux réparer que restaurer, mieux restaure qu'embellir; en aucun cas, il ne faut ajouter ni retrancher.

"Cela est bien dit. Et si les architectes ge bornaient à consolider les vieux monument et ne refaisaient pas, ils mériteraient la reconnaissance de tous les esprits respectueux des souvenirs du passé et des monuments de l'histoire.
Cette citation a été très applaudie.

div.head: Caisse Hypothecaire d'Egypte
div.p: Les Obligations 4 0/0 de la "Caisse hypothécaire d'Egypte" se négocient en banque à 480.

Cet établissement vient d'émettre et place en ce moment en France, en Belgique et en Suisse, des Obligations 4 0/0 de 500 fr. rapportant 20 fr. par an, nets de tous impôts et remboursables en quarante années. Voici ce que nous lisons à propos de cette Société dans les rapports du consul belg- au Caire

"La Caisse hypothécaire d'Egypte, au capital de cinq millions de francs, actions, dont le cinquième seulement est versé, est une société anonyme belge conetituée dans le but de prêter de l'argent, su hypothèques, aux petits propriétaires égyptiens. Les prêts rapportant à la société d 6 1/2 à 7 1/2 0/0 sont consentis pour un durée de temps qui, en général, dépasse cinq ans. La société ne prête sur les immeubles hypothéqués qu'une somme variant entre 55 et 60 0/0 de leur valeur. Le poin
important est de ne pas se tromper sur cette val ur. Les actionnaires ont, sous c rapport, des garanties sérieuses dans 1 compétence spéciale de plusieurs membredu conseil d'administration ".

div.head: LE PORT D'ALEXANDRIE
div.p: L'ENCOMBREMENT DES QUAIS
Monsieur le Directeur
de l'Egyptian Gazette.

L'encombrement des quais n'est pas un fait nouveau pour Alexandrie. Il y a plusieurs années déjà qu'à pareille époque les citations et mises en demeure pleuvent sur la tête des capitaines. Les destinataires de la cargaison, qui n'ignorent point l'agglomération des bateaux dans notre port, ont soin de faire insérer dans la charte-partie une clause spéciale obligeant les capitaines à décharger dans un délai fixé, et les relevant eux-mêmes de tous frais de séjour supplémentaire du navire et de toute in- Jemnité.

Plusieurs procès résultant de cette situation se sont déroulés depuis 1898 devant le tribunal mixte de commerce d'Alexandrie, qui a invariablement donné gain de cause aux capitaines, pris à l'improviste dans un port qu'ils ne connaissaient pas et où ils sont empêchés de débarquer pour des raisons de force majeure. Par contre, la Cour semble devoir consacrer la thèse con- traire. Dans quelques-uns de ses arrêts, elle reléve les destinataires de toute responsabilité pour la faire retomber sur l'Administra. tion du Port; mais, celle-ci n'ayant contracté d'engagements envers personne, les capitaines ne peuvent donc avoir aucun recours coatre elle et, partant, doivent subir seuls les conséquences du retard.
La question en était là lorsque l'affluence énorme de marchandises dans notre port est venue lui donner un regain d'actualité.

Le nombre de bateaux en rade est considérable. Les grandes compagnies de navigation étant pourvues, moyennant des droits d'accostage assez élevés, d'emplacements spéciaux n'ont guère à souffrir de l'agglomération actuelle. Ce sont les bateaux marchands, chargés par des particuliers, qui en sont surtout victimes. Ainsi les charbonniers anglais et les bateaux chargés de fers ou de bois sont obligés de stopper longtemps au large. Le système des mahones est non seulement coûteux mais encore impraticable lorsque les quais eux-mêmes sont encombrés, comme c'est le cas en ce moment.

La raison que vous donnez de l'encombrement des quais dans votre intéressant article de mercredi dernier, à savoir, la mauvaise volonté des négociants importateurs, mérite d'être sérieusement approfondie,et j'espère que si elle fondée, l'administration prendra les mesures que vous suggérez pour y mettre un terme, en attendant que le Gouvernement ait eu le temps nécessaire de pourvoir aux agrandissements projetés et pour lesquels des crédits importants ont été inscrits au budget de l'année 1905.
Agréez, etc.

div.p: SERVICES SANITAIRES.
AVIS.

Alexandrie. le 7 Décembre 1904.
L'Administrateur, (Signé) W. P. CHATAWAY.
AVIS
La Municipalité met en adjudication la fourniture
des article divers, bois, fer, elous, cuirs, peintures, eto, to, nécessaires au service de Nettoiement pour l'année 1905.
Le osutionnement est fixé à 15% du montant des offres.
Le cahier des charges est déposé au Bureau de Nett iement où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les Jours fériés exceptée.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 20 décembre 1904.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5 h. p.m. L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour fourniture des divers matériels nécessaires."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra Stre remis au Secrétaire Financier avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 20 décembre 1904 à midi.
L'Administrateur, (Signé) W. P. CHATAWAY.
Alexandrie, le 29 Novembre 1904.

div.head: Alexandria General Produce Association.
div.p: COTTON SECTION.
Résumé of answers received in November 1904.
The month of November has not been favorable; the cotton plants have been injured by too cool weather and early rains.
The remnant of the second crop has suffered and

the opening of the bolis of the top crop which was already compromised has almost completely ceased. The yield at the gins continues to be unsatisfactory and the average decrease of 2-8 0/0 on the result of 1908, which we mentioned in our last résumé, tends to go on increasing.

We are therefore of the opinion that the preceding estimate must be increased, and taking into consideration the larger extent of land culti vated in Upper-Egypt and the good yield in ginning obtained there, we are led to estimate the erop at only about 6 million cantars.
ACREAGE
We are indebted to His Excellency the Financial Minister for the following tab'e showing the acreage for 1904 which we append as follows:-

row.cell: making a grand total for 1904 of

div.p: We are much obliged to His Excellency for this kind communication; nevertheless, in comparing the figures with the result of the crop, especially in Charkieh and Galioubieh provinces, we are inclined to consider them to be rather below the reality.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINING.
div.p: HONOUR FOR MR. ALFORD.
Mr. C. I. Alford, of the Egyptian Mines Exploration Company, has been elected vice-president of the Institution of Mining and Metallurgy.
NILE VALLEY.
The following news of the progress of operations has been received under date of Wednesday week :-

"No. 2 Level north (the distance driven is) 25ft.; assay varies between nothing and 11 oz. South (the distance driven is) 58ft. ; the highest assay of the ore is 13dwt. to the ton. No. 5 shaft have struck a strong body of water."
NORTH NILE VALLEY.

North Nile Valleys are now attracting as much attention as the shares of the parent company, and dealings in Nubia (Sudan) Developments are on a large scale. The latter company owns properties adjoining those of the Nile Valley, and its concessions cover a total area of 24,000 square miles. The capital of £100,000 is small, and the vendors took shares only (50,000) for the property. Dealings are now confined to the 25,000 working capital shares, which are quoted at about premium, and look like going better when one has regard to the imminence of certain sub-flotations.
THE UM RUS FLOTATION.

Presiding yesterday week at the meeting of the Mysore Reefs and General Exploration Company, Mr. John Harvey said that a year ago when he addressed the shareholders the concession known as Um Rus was being exploited. In February last it became necessary, under their agreement with the Egyptian Mines Exploration Company, to bring out a company to take over that property. The time was unfortunate, as the prospectus appeared two days after the outbreak of war between Russia and Japan. However, the number of shares which was stated in the prospectus as the limit on which they would go to allotment was subscribed for. Since then work had been carried on with the greatest vigour. Fortnightly reports from the manager were sent to the Stock Exchange and were published in various papers, but for the past two months these reports had not appeared because development opera- tions were stopped in order to strip the shaft and prepare it for hoisting the ore. All the machinery necessary for stamping had been sent out and was in course of erection, and the superintendent reported that there were 9,000 tons of quartz ready for extraction, The mine looked as well as ever, and it was hoped early in the year to begin crushing. He did not suppose that there was any other mine only five miles from the sea and within three weeks of London. They could lay down machinery and coal at a reasonable rate. There seemed to be no difficulty with regard to the question of labour, and no doubt as the development or the mine was proceeded with more hands would come in. The Egyptian mines seemed to be attracting attention from all parts of the world. It was true that the lodes so far were not very wide, but they could not tell what depth might show. The company had the right to prospect over a large portion of territory over there, but not much had yet been done in that direction. He moved the adoption of the report. Mr. Wilde said that he considered the report satisfactory, and he believed that the old com- pany would now get out of the bad odour in which it had been so long. A shareholder asked if some of the company's Um Rus shares could not be distributed in, the form of a dividend. The Chairman said it was too early yet to say anything definite on that matter, but there was a dividend looming in the distance.
CAPE TO CAIRO RAILWAY.
FURTHER EXTENSION.

A further extension of the Cape to Cairo railway to a point 350 miles north of the Zambesi was decided upon last week. Sir Charles Metcalfe, consulting engineer of the railway, who is now superintending the work on the Zambesi, reports that rapid progress is being made with the line to the north of Victoria Falls, and it is expected that the railhead will be at Kalomo, the administrative centre of North-West Rhodesia (Barotseland), early next year. From Kalomo, which is 100 miles north of the Zambesi, in pursuance of the decision reached last week, work will be continued in a north-eastern direction to Broken Hill, a point 250 miles beyond Kalomo.

div.head: FALSE PROPHETS.
div.p: The execution of the death sentence on the two remaining disciples of the false prophet Issa ibn Mariam created a profound and excellent impression on the fanatical inhabitants of Sinya Mark. The death sentence was carried out in the presence of a large crowd of spectators, who came from all the villages to view the spectacle. Mr. Iles, Department Inspector, was in charge of the execution.

Another so-called "waly" or saint has made his appearance in the adjoining Markaz of Sennar. His followers believe that he is a great man and able to do anything he likes. They have ascertained that he never prays in the Sudan, but at Mecca, where he was seen by numerous pilgrims performing his devotions. The new saint and his Derwishes, as they claim to be, were arrested in Kassala and sent to their own Moudirieh, which is Sennar. They are all now in prison and will shortly be released on condition that they never come here again or bother themselves about false saints, but will cultivate their lands and gain their livelihood by the sweat of their brow.

div.head: WAD MEDANI.
div.p: A number of private persons intend to begin building convenient dwellings at Wad Medani for Government employés. Accommodation at that important Blue Nile town is very bad, as most of the houses are made of straw, called "kattah," or of mud. The military are accommodated suitably, as they have spacious apartments situated in the best quarter of the town, but the Government seems to pay little heed to the civilians at Wad Medani, who are compelled during winter to wade in mud and water in order to reach their houses.

div.head: CHRISTIANITY IN THE SUDAN.
div.p: I was much pleased to read in a recent number of the Gazette that an endeavour is being made to establish Christian mission stations in the Sudan. These are greatly needed. In the Sudan Christians live like pagans, hearing and seeing absolutely nothing in the way of outward signs of Christianity, and having no opportunity, in consequence, of joining in public worship. The great increase in the number of Sudanese who become Moslems, which some European papers have reported, has not taken place lately. It was so in the time of the Dervishes, when slave dealers invaded the Sudan and compelled all slaves and negroes to become Mahomedans, but now these have been got rid of and freedom is given to all there is no increase whatever. Christianity can do much good in the Sudan, and Government should give every assistance it can to missionaries who want to establish stations here.

div.head: BLUE NILE.
div.p: The Blue Nile has now fallen, and in a week's time it will be impossible for steamers. to run south of Khartoum. Boats will replace them.

div.head: THE CROPS.
div.p: This year the crops may be considered bad, t as the ardeb of dura is sold at P.T. 80. In prosperous years an ardeb is worth P.T. 20, or less.

div.head: THE WEATHER.
div.p: It is becoming colder and colder, now that the rainy season is over. In November, December, January, and February there is scar cely any rain in the Sudan. The rainy months are August, September, and October. We are well supplied with all kinds of vegetables, melons, etc.

div.head:
EGYPT AND ITALY.
TRADE RELATIONS.
div.p: The approaching establishment of a branch

g of the Banco di Roma at Alexandria, and afterwards at Cairo, has been hailed by the newspapers as a factor in the commercial development of Italian trade with Egypt. It is t curious that Italy, with its important trade h with Egypt, has never thought of establishing n a branch of one of her banks in Egypt before now.
The Italian commercial delegate at Cairo reports to the Minister of Commerce, that in the last industrial exhibition in Cairo, the Italian industrial section occupied the first place.

The enormous agricultural development of Egypt (and therefore of agricultural machines) and the increase in light railways, have led to considerable augmentation in our exports to Egypt of lubricating oils for machinery. For instance, in 1899 Egypt imported lubricating oils to the value of L.E. 30,578. In 1903 these figures went up to L.E. 50,490. The principal importers of this oil were England, the United States, Germany, Belgium, Italy, and France. Last year England ceded the first place to the U.S.A., and Italy has increased her oil exports from L.E. 6,000 to L.E. 16,570. So that Italy occupies a conspicuous place in the import of lubricating oil,in which she has beaten Germany and Belgium. We hope to be the first and in future the only providers of lubricating oils for Egypt. Italy's activity in cotton spinning is marvel-

lous. She is gaining ground in the Eastern markets over England, and she will soon become a serious competitor with England in this branch of industry. Many Egyptian princes have passed through Italy lately en route to sunny Egypt.
